1454448

CAREER: Impact of Urbanization on Organic Carbon-Metal Interactions and Trophic Transfer in Streams

In an increasingly urbanizing landscape, the negative impact of metals from both stormwater and wastewater effluent on organisms in streams will continue to rise. While the focus of most metal bioavailability models for stream organisms is on ambient exposure to dissolved metal phases, this proposed research also addresses the integral role of attachment and ingestion of organic matter in controlling bio-uptake of metals. At the ecosystem scale, the biodynamics of metal uptake and retention relate to both metal and organic matter characteristics, exposure patterns and feeding behavior of stream organisms. Assessment of metal speciation and size distribution as well as organic matter characteristics as related to metal uptake is required knowledge for the development of ecosystem level exposure assessment models that are useful for establishing management strategies for streams. In addition to the proposed research, the education plan will support the training of 1 M.S. and 1 Ph.D. student and at least 2 undergraduate researchers. Enhanced student training will focus on additional coursework in related disciplines and communication skills to promote interdisciplinary research in the future. Educational modules will be developed for K-12 classrooms according to State education guidelines. These modules will be disseminated through the DaVinci program at the University of Connecticut to broaden their reach beyond an individual classroom. A significant aspect of this project will be integrating ecology and environmental engineering across all levels of education through a focus on basic understanding and communication across disciplines: Several interdisciplinary problem-based learning exercises will be developed for university level education and K-12 education modules related to stream impairment will be developed and distributed widely.

This career development plan addresses the research and education challenges associated with developing more effective management strategies for impaired streams in urban areas. The existing framework to assess and manage impaired streams does not address the dynamic and unique conditions present in streams. Metals such as copper and zinc are both necessary and toxic depending on the concentration, and are one of the most common causes of impairment. However, the strong interaction with organic matter across all size ranges and differences in exposure patterns of the effluent and stormwater sources of impairment are dramatic. Total metal loads are not necessarily good indicators of bio-uptake and both metal lability and ingestion of the different organic-metal particulates must be considered. In order to address the stream impairment issues associated with different metal sources, a more complete understanding of metal bio-uptake under urban stream conditions is required.  To accomplish this, the following objectives and approach will be: 1) Quantify the variability of metal speciation and size distribution in different stream source waters across space and time: Automated samplers will collect time interval and flow-weighted samples of effluent and stormwater runoff, respectively, at impaired sites across a range of urban to suburban sites. Samples will be separated into size fractions relevant to biotic uptake and analyzed for total metals, organic matter, colloidal metal and organic matter size distribution, and organic matter optical, chemical and metal binding characteristics. 2) Identify metal speciation and size distribution predictors of biological uptake in primary producers and higher trophic level organisms and the dependence on metal loading dynamics: Metal uptake and attachment will be analyzed as a function of size distribution and chemical characteristics of the organic matter in different source waters. Biodynamic modeling will assess the net metal uptake into algae and subsequent transfer to higher trophic level organisms. These will be examined under exposure regimes that mimic the stream, e.g. with different ratios of source water to stream water for effluent sources and varying exposure concentrations for stormwater runoff.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most common causes of impairment in streams is metal contamination. In more developed landscapes, those metals, such as copper, enter streams through stormwater runoff and wastewater effluent. Copper is a necessary metal for all organisms, but can be toxic at elevated concentrations. What is not considered very closely, is that the form of copper and the interactions copper has with the other constituents in the water, such as organic matter from leaf litter decay or wastewater processes, can have a very large impact on how copper interacts with organisms in the stream.

We have studied the form of copper coming from wastewater treatment plant effluent, stormwater runoff that directly enters streams, and stormwater runoff that passes through systems such as stormwater wetlands.  Each water source has different characteristics, with more organic matter present in wastewater effluent that can strongly bind copper, limiting its interaction with organisms, more and larger organic matter in stormwater runoff that can lead to more attachment or ingestion in stream organisms, or more iron oxide bound copper, in effect a tiny particle of rust with copper attached to it, that may also get ingested by stream organisms.  The possible forms of copper, and the conditions under which they form helps to more accurately assess the potential impacts in streams and helps define the laboratory assays used to measure stream impairment.

The current accepted practice to identify impairment of streams relies on two key measures: biological criteria and aquatic life criteria. The biological criteria include an assessment of species richness based on the expected groups of organisms present in a stream. In many low order streams this has predominantly been surveys of macroinvertebrates, many of which are common insects known to fly fishers. The aquatic life criteria were established by the EPA under the Clean Water Act and sets toxic concentrations based on toxicity assays with organisms that do not represent this major class of sensitive insect organisms present in streams. Aquatic insects are one of the first groups of species to disappear from impaired streams and thus their lack of integration into setting the aquatic life criterion is concerning. The difficulty in establishing a toxicity assay for insects is in replicating their growth conditions and life cycle in a repeatable laboratory assay. One particularly important aspect is their food supply, which for some of the most sensitive insects is the periphyton, or mixture of green algae, diatoms and bacteria that grow in the streambed. More closely matching the food source in the laboratory to the food source in the stream can lead to more accurate toxicity assays.

We measured the rate of copper uptake and efflux in green algae, and later periphyton exposed to either wastewater or stormwater sources of organic matter with varying concentrations of copper.  The amount of copper uptake in algae and periphyton was dependent on the organic matter source. For instance, with wastewater sourced organic matter, the copper uptake in periphtyon was lower than with the same concentration of stormwater sourced organic matter. Since stormwater exposure is not constant and only happens in the days following rainfall, we measured the copper concentration over time following stormwater exposure and found that it was also dependent on source of organic matter, with a slower rate of copper loss from periphyton exposed to stormwater. This suggests that periphyton, a dominant food source for some insects in streams, that are exposed to copper coming from stormwater, are potentially contributing to elevated levels of copper in aquatic insects in streams with more stormwater exposure. Depending on the life cycle of the insect and the seasonality of the rainfall in the area, organisms may be exposed to higher copper at more sensitive times in their life cycle, likely partly explaining the differences observed in insect populations in impaired streams.

This project also resulted in the integration of ecological education into the environmental engineering curriculum and now requires all students to take a course in ecological processes and treatment systems, focused on stormwater and wastewater treatment. An annual week-long workshop is also hosted for K-12 educators to share ongoing research about stream health and metal impairments and to stimulate the generation of new classroom activities appropriate to the age levels and curriculum. Educators engage with the environmental engineering students in both hands-on activities and in discussing career options. College students are engaged in both explaining and creating environmental engineering activities to share with K-12 students to both explain how humans impact the environment and how engineered systems can help mitigate those impacts.
